content: is really wonderful how much resilience there is in human nature let any
obstructing cause no matter what be removed in any way even by death and we
fly back to first principles of hope and enjoyment
hey guys welcome back to black magic
crafts you know this week I really needed a project that was just for me
just something I wanted to do something fun that allowed me to escape into the
Hobby I loved and I actually decided to paint a mini which is a bit odd because
that's not my favorite part of the Hobby my favorite part of the hobby is making
little dioramas and decorative bases and that sort of thing so I decided to paint
a mini so I could do that I've had this little guy in my collection unpainted
for quite some time it's a vampire model from crippled god foundry that was made
available through a Kickstarter they launched quite some time ago now this is
not a sponsored video they have no idea I'm making it but I did get this mini
from them a long time ago from a promotional video I did for them and
I've always wanted to paint it I've just never got around to it but finally I did
just mostly so I could justify building this cool little diorama I don't think
this mini is yet available on the retail market I think it's still just a
Kickstarter exclusive but I will put a link to draw boundaries webstore
so you can take a look for yourself maybe find something else they're a
really wonderful little independent company and I'd love to help support
them in these challenging times so I spent the afternoon painting him and it
was a nice relaxing exercise I didn't go crazy and spend a week painting him you
know I'm not that kind of guy I spent a couple hours and got him to a point
where I thought he looked nice enough to put on a little display some people will
argue it's not an amazing paint job and it's not but it's good enough for me and
that's what counts but once I had him painted I could shift
my focus and start building him a neat little diorama I knew right from the
start that I wanted him standing on top or below a set of stairs
perhaps in a doorway I used XPS insulation foam for essentially the
entire build and it was all made from one large cylinder that I cut out right
at the beginning
looking for an easy way to make steps at the right scale I cut my half circle
into a bunch of very thin layers
initially I tried to take a lazy approach of gluing together the layers
and simply offsetting them the idea was that I could then just cut back to the
one and and square it up and be left with a great-looking set of stairs that
required no cutting in between each layer surprise surprise I was wrong I
quickly realized that this would cause a problem as the half circle shifted it
meant that cutting them flush would create a narrowing effect that I didn't
want this must have been the result of the circle not being perfect or
something I'm not really quite sure so I set to work with a more tedious but
much more effective method of keeping the layers aligned to their original
orientation each time cutting away a bit more to create the steps
this worked much better I'd saved the
inner circle I cut away and was able to place it back in to create the inner
wall of the stairwell then I cut it in half to make a flat side of the display
I thought it would be cool to make the other wall as well and create a very
narrow diorama this is a bit unusual I think but I think it's pretty cool I was
able to easily do this by thinning a remnant of the cylinder that I already
had as a cut off then I made a cutout for an MDF window frame before drawing
in my brickwork something worth noting here is that I'm using the German
styrofoam which typically takes pencil imprints better than the pink or blue
stuff we get in North America but this is entirely dependent on the direction
of the foam it works much better from one side than the other and the
orientation of the foam that I had cut the cylinder out of meant I was working
with the crappy side that doesn't hold the imprint as well meaning this effect
was almost identical if not maybe even worse than the pink or the blue stuff
that I sometimes use
I wanted to close up the backside of the piece so I glued on some medium weight
chipboard let that dry then cut off the excess I did the same thing to the
bottom to give the finished piece more strength rather than having the last
step show a layer of chipboard underneath I actually cut out the base
in a way that created a final step the thickness worked out perfectly for this
and hit the base layer in plain sight it also made the front and most
vulnerable step a lot stronger than if it had just been foam personally I
thought this was the most clever part of the whole project I also wanted to
protect the back of the curved foam now chipboard would be too thick for this so
instead I just attached some construction paper using super 77 spray
adhesive going overboard I super glued all the joints then going way overboard
I saturated all of the paper in super glue this basically turns the paper into
plastic on a point now I only did a bit of this on camera as this much super
glue vapor is hard on the eyes and not good to breathe in
so actually finish this process off camera outside
even with my shop ventilation my fan and my windows I felt it was better to step
outside for this then they filled in all the seams with milliput this would be a
very hard and durable solution much better than just regular joint compound
the nice thing is that I was actually able to sculpt in details in the areas
where the foam and chipboard met on the sides i could add the grout lines and
continue the stone this way I could hide that outer layer and seam
and of course before painting I sealed everything with my Mod Podge and black
paint mixture then I primed the whole thing with flat black spray primer and I
decided to mostly airbrush this piece for a bit of practice
I used a medium grey followed by a very light almost white then I applied my
homemade black wash something odd and surprising happened here the wash
started to remove my layer of paint I've never had this happen before but I was
trying a different type of paint from the usual Viejo or Reaper that I use
considering my wash has no solvents in it I was surprised that the airbrush
paint was so easily removed with water but I guess it's water soluble good to
know the paint applied really nicely so I'd like to continue using it but I'll
make sure to seal it before applying wash in the future I figured I'd try to
turn a failure into a happy accident so I just wiped away all of the loose wet
paint and tried to utilize the splotchy look to give this stone a cool effect I
thought I'd be a bit brave and step away from gray stone and apply a green ink
I've never done this before but I really wanted to try it I thought this would
contrast nicely with the vampires red cloak and I'm really happy that I did
with the painting basically done I could move on to the window I painted the
frame and iron color with a bit of rust and used a leaded glass sheet from
shifting lands Calm if you don't have access to something like this I have a
previous video where I show you how you can create a very similar and maybe even
better looking effect using household items I will link that in the info cards
above the sheet I used was clear but I wanted purple glass so I simply glued it
to some purple construction paper before adding it to the piece for a fun little
detail I applied some cotton from a q-tip using some superglue to make an
easy little spiderweb effect when I painted the model I'd given him
some blood drips using UV resin I wanted to continue that theme on the base so I
mixed up some red ink with Vallejo water texture to create some blood effects I
could place on the floor I like the idea of implying that he drained some victim
off-screen so to speak so I created a pool coming from the
black section of hall I made a few drips that followed the count this is a small
detail that you can only really see from certain angles but it's a fun one for
people to discover as they look at the piece I'm really happy with the way this
turned out and I'm really glad that I let myself take on the project there's a
lot easier and a lot faster than I had expected
I built the thing in one afternoon and painted it the next day and it was fun
every step of the way I hope you guys enjoyed this video I certainly enjoyed
making this project and it was an excellent bit of self-care in these
trying times and I highly recommend you find some projects like this for
yourself if you can find the time if you like this video hit the like button let
me know in the comments section below because going out and shopping for craft
supplies and hobby supplies is not really advised at the moment I suggest
now more than ever you check out black magic craft CA where I have my essential
equipment page where I list all of the stuff that I use and recommend and there
are links to where you can order it safely online if you enjoy these videos
that I make each and every week and if they're helping you maybe you can help
me help you and help others you can do that by supporting the channel on
patreon joining the fellowship gives you access to the black magic craft discord
server Facebook group but most important it gives me the means to continue making
these videos for the community for you and for myself and I'd really love to
have you as the newest member that's it for this week guys I will see you again
next week Cheers
